content.definition: Pathology affecting the radial artery and considerations for its use as conduit. The radial artery is increasingly used for coronary bypass (CABG) and serves as access for coronary intervention. Complications include occlusion, pseudoaneurysm, and hand ischemia if palmar arch is incomplete.

anatomy.origin: Brachial artery bifurcation at antecubital fossa
anatomy.course: Lateral forearm → anatomic snuffbox → deep palmar arch
anatomy.relations: Superficial, palpable between FCR and brachioradialis

clinical_uses: Radial artery access for PCI (transradial approach)

allen_test.purpose: Assess palmar arch completeness before radial harvest/access
allen_test.technique: Compress radial and ulnar arteries, release ulnar only

prevention_of_RAO: Patent hemostasis (allow antegrade flow during compression)

clinical_pearls: Allen test mandatory before radial artery harvest or prolonged access
RAO often asymptomatic due to ulnar collateral
Radial artery graft patency comparable to saphenous vein in CABG
Transradial PCI reduces access site bleeding vs femoral
Radial artery spasm managed with nitroglycerin, verapamil

learning_objectives: Understand radial artery conduit use in CABG
